note_models.name: Cloze
Basic
Image Occlusion Enhanced

tmpls.name: IO Card

flds.name: Hide others on the back side

note_models.name: Cloze (Hide all)

tmpls.afmt:
<script>
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
setTimeout(function() {
    var clozeBoxes = document.querySelector(".cloze cloze2_w");
    var elements = document.querySelectorAll("cloze2." + clozeBoxes.className);
    for(var i = 0 ; i < elements.length ; i++) {
        elements[i].style.display="inline";
    }
}, 0);
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
</script>


<script>
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
setTimeout(function() {
    var clozeBoxes = document.querySelector(".cloze cloze2_w");
    var elements = document.querySelectorAll("cloze2." + clozeBoxes.className);
    for(var i = 0 ; i < elements.length ; i++) {
        elements[i].classList.add("cloze");
        elements[i].style.display="inline";
    }
}, 0);
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
</script>



{{cloze:Text}}
{{#Extra}}
<hr>
{{Extra}}
{{/Extra}}

{{#Hide others on the back side}}
<style>
cloze2 {
    display: none;
}

cloze2_w {
    display: inline-block;
    width: 5em;
    height: 1em;
    background-color: #ffeba2;
}

.cloze cloze2 {
    display: inline;
}

.cloze cloze2_w {
    display: none;
}

cloze2.reveal-cloze2 {
    display: inline;
}

cloze2_w.reveal-cloze2 {
    display: none;
}

.cloze2-toggle {
    -webkit-appearance: none;
    display: block;
    font-size: 1.3em;
    height: 2em;
    background-color: #ffffff;
    width: 100%;
    margin-top: 20px;
}

.cloze2-toggle:active {
    background-color: #ffffaa;
}
</style>

<script>
function toggle() {
var elements = document.querySelectorAll('cloze2, cloze2_w');
    for(var i = 0 ; i < elements.length ; i++) {
        elements[i].classList.toggle('reveal-cloze2');
    }
}
</script>

<button class='cloze2-toggle' onclick='toggle()'>Toogle mask</button>
{{/Hide others on the back side}}
tmpls.name: Cloze (Hide all)

cloze2 {

}

cloze2_w {

}
</style>
{{cloze:Text}}

tmpls.qfmt:
{{#Image}}

fields:
Stratum corneum
{{c1::15-20::how many?}} layers thick, {{c2::flattened::round/flattened}}, {{c3::non-nucleated::nucleated/not nucleated}} keratinized cells.

Stratum corneum
cytoplasm is filled with {{c1::birefringent filamentous keratins}}.

Stratum Corneum
Cells contain only {{c1::amorphous}} proteins.

Stratum Corneum
cells are called "{{c1::squames}}"
Melanocytes produce two types of melanin. They are {{c1::eumelanin}} and {{c2::pheomelanin}}. {{c3::Pheomelanin}} is the pigment found in red hair.
Other than melanocytes, these are two other ways to add color to skin. {{c1::Carotene}} and {{c2::blood vessels}}.
Melanocytes are derived from {{c1::neural crest cells}}.
Other than melanocytes being derived from neural crest cells, what other tissue is derived from neural crest cells? {{c1::Pulp, dentin, periodontium, odontoblast}}
One melanocyte per {{c1::5-6::number}} {{c2::basal::type of cell}} cells

Melanocyte morphology
-{{c1::Rounded cell}} bodies
-connect to {{c1::basal lamina}} via {{c2::hemidesmosomes}}
-do not form desmosomes with {{c3::basal}} cells
-long {{c3::dendritic processes}} extending into {{c4::epidermis}}
-{{c4::pale}} staining, numerous mitochondria, RER, Golgi

Melanocytes
{{c1::tyrosinase}} converts {{c2::tyrosine}} to {{c1::DOPA}}-> melanin

Melanocytes
melanin is stores in granules called {{c1::melanosomes}}.

Melanocytes
melanosomes are taken up by {{c1::keratinocutes}}, form {{c1::protective cap}} around keratinized nucleus, protect DNA from {{c1::UV irradiation}}

Langerhans Cells
-also called {{c1::dendritic}} cells
-act as {{c1::antigen presenting cells::what do they show}}
-most evident in stratum {{c1::spinosum}}
-{{c1::processes}} extend between {{c2::keratinocytes}}
-derived from {{c3::hemopoietic precursors, blood-borne}}
-bind, process, and present antigens to {{c4::T}} cells.

Merkel Cells
-{{c1::mechanoreceptors::what type of receptor}} 
-similar in appearance to {{c1::keratinocytes}}
-contain dense-core {{c2::neurosecretory}} granules
-located in stratum {{c3::basale}} of epidermis, and also at base of hair follicles
-partially surrounded by {{c4::terminal discs}} of sensory nerve fibers.
The dermis is largely comprised of {{c1::connective}} tissue that lies deep to, and supports the {{c2::epidermis}}.
The dermis separated from the epidermis by a basement membrane which includes {{c1::a basal lamina and a reticular lamina::hint:two layers}}

Dermis
-thickness is {{c1::variable}} -it is thickest in {{c1::the back.}}

Dermis
The interface between the epidermis and the dermis is made up of {{c1::finger-like papillae}}

Dermis
The interface between the epidermis and the dermis is made up of {{c1::finger-like papillae}}
What four sensory nerve endings are encapsulated?

Meissner corpuscles
Pacinian corpuscles
Ruffini's corpuscles
Krause end-bulbs
What is the image shown below?
Pacinian Corpuscle
Meissner corpuscles are {{c1::oval}} shaped and located primarly in {{c1::dermal papillae, fingertips, palms, and soles}}.
The function of Meissner corpuscles is to {{c1::detect light touch}}
Pacinian corpuscles are shaped like {{c1::large, oval, capsule formed of 15-50 concentric rings (looks like an onion)}}
The capsule of pacinian corpuscles surround {{c1::unmyelinated axon::location}} and detect {{c1::coarse touch,pressure, or sustained touch,vibrations::function}}
Ruffini's corpuscles are formed of {{c1::a simple capsule enclosing fluid and terminal arborizations of a sensory neuron::detailed description}}
Stretch and torque are detected by {{c1::Ruffini's corpuscles}}
Thermoreceptors and mechanoreceptors are also known as {{c1::Krause end-bulbs::encapsulated sensory nerve ending}}
Sebaceous glands are located throughout the {{c1::skin, except palms and soles::organ}} and are most dense in {{c1::face and scalp region::location}}
Sebaceous glands typically empty into the {{c1::upper part of hair follicle::location}}
The hair + sebaceous gland is also termed {{c1::pilosebaceous apparatus}}
In hairless regions, sebaceous glands empty directly onto {{c1::epidermal surface}}
Sebaceous gland cells are called {{c1::sebocytes }} because they produce {{c1::sebum}}
Sebum is made up of {{c1::wax esters, cholesterol, triglycerides, etc.}}
Secretion of sebum increases at {{c1::puberty}} and is stimulated by {{c1::testosterone and other androgens in females}}
{{c1::Sebum::Substance}} helps maintain stratum corneum and hair.
Sebum has {{c1::antibacterial}} and {{c1::antifungal}} properties.
{{c1::Eccrine}} sweat glands are most abundant on soles of feet and are present at about 3,000,000 glands per person.
Eccrine sweat glands can produce up to {{c1::10 liters::amount in liters}} of sweat per day!
Eccrine sweat glands are composed of {{c1::coiled secretory units and ducts::structure}}
Clear cells of eccrine sweat glands produce {{c1::sweat}} and dark cells produce {{c1::mucoid substances}}
{{c1::Clear cells::Clear/Dark cells}} in eccrine sweat glands contain abundant mitochondria and microvilli.
{{c1::Dark cells::Clear/Dark cells}} produce glycoprotein involved with the immune response and have bactericidal activity.
{{c1::Myoepithelial cells}} contract to help eccrine sweat glands discharge their secretions
Body releases {{c1::excess salt}} and {{c1::nitrogenous waste}} via sweat
Duct cells of eccrine sweat glands have {{c1::Na+, K+-ATPase::type of pump}} to resorb Na+
{{c1::Apocrine}} sweat glands are confined to axilla and perineal regions.
Apocrine glands have a {{c1::larger::smaller/larger}} lumen than eccrine glands
Apocrine glands are composed of {{c1::cuboidal cells::shape of cell}}, {{c1::eosinophilic::eosinophilic/basophilic}}, and numerous apical {{c1::secretory granules::type of cell}}
Apocrine glands actually function in {{c1::merocrine}} manner.
Merocrine indicates that they do not "pinch off" a portion of the cell during secretion like they do in apocrine, they only release vesicles containing secretory products.
{{c1::F::T/F}} Apocrine sweat glands are confined to the axilla and perineal regions and thus release secretions that contain bad odor.
The secretion is odorless; it acquires its odor due to bacteria
Apocrine glands are innervated by {{c1::adrenergic nerve endings}}
Eccrine glands are innervated by {{c1::cholinergic nerves}}
Hair is derived from {{c1::hair follicles}} and are formed of {{c1::keratinized material}}
All skin has hair follicles except {{c1:: Palms and soles, lips, glans penis, clitoris, labia minora::6 locations}}
{{c1::Terminal hair::Type of hair}}  is long and coarse hair found on the scalp and beard.
{{c1::Vellus hair::Type of hair}} is very fine hair such as in the forehead.

The three cycles of hair growth:
{{c1::anagen}} - hair growth
{{c2::catagen}} - follicle regression
{{c3::telogen}} - period of inactivity
{{c1::Baldness}} is caused by terminal hair follicles transforming to vellus follicles and undergoing periods of telogen.
Facial and pubic hair growth is controlled by {{c1::androgens}}
The {{c1::bulb}} is a dilated base of the hair follicle that contains cells that undergo {{c1::mitosis}} and {{c1::keratinization}} to produce new cells and form hair shaft.
{{c1::Dermal papilla}} invaginate into hair bulb and contain a capillary network necessary for new hair growth.
The {{c1::epithelial root sheath}} is continuous with the bulb and surrounds the {{c1::hair shaft.}}
The muscle that contracts and makes a hair become erect is called the {{c1::arrector pili muscle}}
The purpose of hair becoming erect is allowing {{c1::the trapping of warm air next to the skin}} and works better in {{c1::animals with fur}}
Hair color is caused by {{c1::melanin}} produced by {{c1::melanocytes}} located in the {{c1::bulb}}
The cuticle of the nails is {{c1::stratum corneum::layer of skin}} folding and is called {{c1::eponychium}}
The nail bed is formed of {{c1::basal and spinous::2 answers}} epithelial layers only.
The distal free end of the nail plate is called the {{c1::hyponychium.}}
Color of nail bed indicates {{c1::oxygenation of blood.}}
9b7f0c649b5c41f19cd74cf3f0dd8723-ao-1
9b7f0c649b5c41f19cd74cf3f0dd8723-ao-2
9b7f0c649b5c41f19cd74cf3f0dd8723-ao-3
The largest organin the body is {{c1::skin}}
The skin accounts for {{c1::15%-20%}} of body weight.
What does the integument include?
Skin and its appendages
What three layers does the skin include?
Epidermis, Dermis, and subcutaneous/hypodermal tissue
The epidermis is an epithelial covering of {{c1::ectodermal}} orgin.
{{c1::Hair}}, {{c1::nails}}, {{c1::sweat glands}} and {{c1::sebacious glands}} are derived from the epidermis.
The dermis is {{c2::connective tissue:: what type of tissue}} underlying the epidermis and is of {{c1::mesodermal}} orgin.
What layer is between the epidermis and dermis?
the basement membrane
subcutaneous/hypodermal tissue lies {{c1::deep}} to the dermis
What is superficial fascia?
Another name for the subcutaneous or hypodermal layer
{{c1::Epidermal ridges}} and {{c1::sulci}} on hands and feet form distictive patterns reffered to as fingerprints.
skin is {{c1::elastic}} -- it can stretch to cover swollen areas.
What are the roles of skin? Name 5

protection
sensation 
thermoregulation 
metabolism 
communication
The epidermis is {{c1::stratefied squamous keratinized:: layered, cells shape, and is it keratinized or not }} epithelium.
What types of cells are found in the epidermis? Name 4
Keratinocytes, Melanocytes, Langerhans cells, and Merkel cells
The primary cell type in the epidermis are {{c1::keratinocytes}}
{{c1::Melanocytes}} produce a dark pigment called {{c2::melanin}}
{{c1::Langerhans cells::cell type}} are antigen presenting cells in the epidermis.
{{c1::Merkel cells}} are assosciated with {{c2::sensory nerve fibers. }}
Melanocytes protect {{c1::DNA}} of keratinocytes from UV light.
What is the primary layer of thick skin?
Stratum Corneum
Thin skin ranges from {{c1::75-150 mm}} in thickness.
Thick skin ranges from {{c1::400-1400mm}} in thickness
Thick skin is {{c1::hairless:: amount of hair }} and located on the {{c1::palms of the hands}} and {{c1::soles of the feet.}}
f60fe89f31084c03b9b950ab8ed1ee43-ao-1
f60fe89f31084c03b9b950ab8ed1ee43-ao-2
f60fe89f31084c03b9b950ab8ed1ee43-ao-3
f60fe89f31084c03b9b950ab8ed1ee43-ao-4
f60fe89f31084c03b9b950ab8ed1ee43-ao-5
f60fe89f31084c03b9b950ab8ed1ee43-ao-6
Stratum basale is also known as the {{c1::basal layer}}
The stratum basale is {{c1::a single layer::how many layers}} of {{c2::cuibodal to columnar::cell shape}} {{c3::basophilic::basophilic or eosinophilic}} cells.
The statum basale is separated from the underlying dermis by {{c1::basal lamina::what layer}}
Basal cells attach to the basal lamina by {{c1::hemidesmesomes::type of junction}} and to other basal cells by {{c1::desmisomes::type of junction}}.
The basal cells making up the statum basale undergo frequent mitosis, thus acting as {{c1::stem cells}} for the other layers of the epidermis.
Stratum spinosum is refered to as the {{c1::spinous}} or {{c1::prickle}} layer
What is the thickest layer of the epidermis?
Stratum Spinosum
Cells of the stratum spinosum are {{c1::polyhedral::shape}} cells with {{c2::central::central or peripheral}} nuclei.
Which layer of the epidermis has cells whose cytoplasm actively synthesizes keratin in form of tonobrils which attach to desmesomes?
Stratum spinosum
Why is the stratum spinosum layer known as spinous or prickle pair?
when tissues are processed, cells shrink but remain attached at desmesomes giving appearance of "spines"
Stratum granulosum is the {{c1::granular}} layer.
Stratum granulosum contains {{c1::3-5::how many layers}} layers of {{c1::flattened::flattened or cuboidal}} cells.
The cytoplasm of the stratum granulosum layer contains {{c1::keratohyalin}} granules.
The keratohyalin granules in stratum granulosum contain {{c1::filaggrin}} and other proteins involved in keratinization.
{{c1::Stratum lucidum::layer of the epidermis}} in only seen in thick skin
The Stratum lucidum is a translucent layer formed of {{c1::flattened::flattened or rounded}} {{c2::eosinophilic::basophilic otr eosinoophilic}} cells when stained with HE.
The {{c1::nuclei and organelles}} have been lost in cells of the stratum lucidum.
Cells making up the stratum lucidum epidermal layer are packed with {{c1::keratin fillaments.}}
